Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Summary of Comments on Tipping System Reform

The comments reveal widespread dissatisfaction with the current tipping system, with most participants expressing concerns about its expansion and implementation. A significant portion of respondents favor either eliminating tipping entirely or substantially reforming the system.

Key Concerns Raised

Tipping Culture Expansion: Many participants feel that tipping requests have expanded beyond traditional service contexts. People report feeling pressured to tip for basic transactions where minimal service is provided, with constant tipping menu pop-ups creating frustration during routine purchases.

Wage Structure Issues: A recurring theme throughout the comments is the relationship between tipping and wages. Multiple respondents emphasize that workers should receive livable base wages rather than relying heavily on tips for income. There's strong support for businesses taking responsibility for fair employee compensation.

Voluntary vs. Mandatory: Participants distinguish between voluntary tipping for quality service and feeling coerced to tip. While some acknowledge tipping as a way to reward good service, most oppose mandatory tipping requirements or social pressure to tip regardless of service quality.

Proposed Solutions

Several alternatives were suggested: - Complete elimination of the tipping system - Requiring businesses to pay livable wages to all employees - Making tipping truly optional without social pressure - Implementing reciprocal benefits for tippers (thank you notes, coupons) - Shifting from percentage-based to fixed-amount tipping - Reserving tips exclusively for exceptional service

Diverse Perspectives

While the majority favor reform, perspectives vary on implementation. Some participants continue to tip at every establishment out of concern for workers' welfare, while others advocate for higher standard tip amounts. However, the prevailing sentiment supports structural changes to ensure fair wages without relying on customer gratuities.

The comments reflect a desire for a more equitable system that fairly compensates workers while removing the burden and social awkwardness of constant tipping decisions from customers.

Summary B

Summary of Comments on the Tipping System

The comments reveal significant dissatisfaction with the current tipping system, with many participants expressing frustration about its expansion beyond traditional service contexts. A recurring theme is the feeling of being pressured or "bullied" into tipping, particularly with digital payment systems that make it uncomfortable to decline. Many note that tipping requests now appear in situations where no actual service is provided, such as picking up takeout orders.

Key Concerns About Current System

A substantial portion of respondents feel that tipping has become "out of control" and "over-expected" in the United States. They express frustration with: - Point-of-sale systems that default to high tip percentages - Being asked to tip before receiving service - The expansion of tipping to non-service transactions - The awkwardness of declining to tip in face-to-face interactions

Proposed Solutions

The most common suggestion is to eliminate tipping entirely and ensure workers receive livable base wages. Many participants point to European models where service charges are incorporated into prices. Specific recommendations include:

  • Paying service workers minimum wage or higher so they don't rely on tips
  • Making tipping purely optional for exceptional service
  • Implementing a standard service charge (such as 10%) instead of variable tipping
  • Redesigning payment systems to make "no tip" options more accessible
  • Restricting tip requests to situations involving actual service
Perspectives on Tipping Practice

While most comments are critical of the system, some participants maintain positive views about tipping when it's voluntary and merit-based. These individuals: - Always tip at restaurants and for delivery services - Believe in rewarding good service - Recognize that workers currently depend on tips due to low base wages - View tipping as a way to show appreciation for hard work

Overall, the comments suggest strong support for reforming the tipping system, with most favoring either its elimination or significant restructuring to reduce pressure on consumers while ensuring fair compensation for workers.

[Question]

What is your opinion on tipping, and if given the chance, how would you improve or change the current tipping system?

answer.text_box: I think tipping has become excessive in places where the workers are already earning a fair wage as opposed to earning a server’s wage. I also think that in some countries where tipping isn’t the norm, workers provide good service because it’s their job whereas in America, they are doing it to try and earn a good tip.
